title: Meters - nonideal - V reading in circuits 1 2 3

content.question:
Three circuits, Circuit <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Circuit <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and Circuit <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, are constructed. The figure shows a portion of one of the circuits. Except for the meters being ideal or nonideal in the different circuits, the portion shown is identical for each circuit and the ammeter current has the same value <math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> for all three circuits. The table indicates which meters are ideal and which are nonideal.
AmmeterVoltmeterCircuit <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>IdealIdealCircuit <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>IdealNonidealCircuit <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>NonidealIdeal
Which of the following correctly ranks the voltmeter readings <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> in the three circuits?

choices.label: <math alttext="V sub 1 equals V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="V sub 1 is greater than V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="V sub 3 is greater than V sub 1, which equals V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="V sub 3 is greater than V sub 2, which is greater than V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="V sub 3 is greater than V sub 1, which equals V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
